description: He had no right to do that.  He could have a guirdian appointed or someone to make that decision.
A homeless man with no identification came into an emergency room and was kept alive through a respirator. He would live a maximum of two weeks; so Dr. Bennet decided to let him die instead.
A homeless man came in and had to be put on life support to stay alive.  His dr thought it was a crappy wa to live and unplugged his life suport system.

The other option would be for the doctor to continue to allow him to live on life support; which would only buy him a couple of weeks. There's always a slim chance that he could wake up; but it's very doubtful. I believe that the doctor made the right decsion.
The homeless guy was going to die one way or the other so the doctor took him off the machine.

Though I agree with the doctor about the patient dying with dignity; it's not up to him to make that decision. He is not responsible for the patient regarding decisions nor his he the power of attorney. He must treat the patient's signs and symptoms and lt nature take it's course.
A unconcious homeless man was rushed into the hospital with his organs shutting down.  The doctor took him off the respirator to let him die with dignity.

he could have done nothing and waited for the man to die.  he could have called relatives of the patient and get their input.  he could have talked to his supervisor and asked for advice.  he could have inquired to find out if their were written records; ike a living will; to see what the patient would have wanted.  he could have done one or more of these.
A homeless man comes in; in bad shape. He's only living because of machines hooked up to him. The doctor decides its not a good way to live; and unhooks the machines.
He could of thought about his family and made it their decision; he could of let him live.

Dr. Bennett; an emergency room physician; decides that a homeless man should die with dignity instead of spend his last week or two hooked up to a respirator.  So; he decides to remove him from the machine to end his suffering.
a doctor killed a homeless man out of pity.
A homeless man that was going to die was hooked up to equipment to keep him alive.  The doctor discounted him because he would have only lasted another two weeks and died anyways

I feel like the doctor disconnected the homeless man because he felt that if the man was able to judge his situation; he would not want to live. The only alternative would have been to let the man live on for the two weeks; but it wouldn't have benefited nyone; at all; not even the patient.
Homeless man is on life support and the Dr. took him off it to not have him live like this.
A dying homeless man is brought to the ER. The doctor decides to hasten his death by taking him off the respirator.
A man comes in to the hospital and is unresponsive. The doctor decides to let the man die with dignity and unplugs the machines that would keep him alive. The man dies.
He couldve let him live for a week or two and tried to find his family so that they may pay their last respects.
He could've tried to help him. Miracles happen. It wasn't really his decision.
He could have left him hooked up to the respirator and let him live for another two weeks. Although he would not be awake.
He could have cared for the man to the best of his medical ability; but it would have been pointless.
Dr. Bennett saved a man from suffering
He decided that since the man would only live two more weeks and never be conscious again; that he'd disconnect him from the respirator. He could've waited; but he didn't.
I think the doctor made the right decision. Although it is really truly terrible; I think that it was right for him to die with dignity.

A homeless man was brought to the hospital; and he could not survive withour a respirator.  Even then his time would be extremely limited.  The doctor decided; without concent; to put the man out of his misery immediately by disconnecting the respirator.
A man is dying; so is put on a respirator to live for another week or two. The doctor pulls the plug on the patient to end his suffering.
homeless man comes in with no chance of living without assisted help.  would eventually die anyways without regaining consciousness.  dr. makes decision to take him off life support.

A homeless man was brought into an emergency room almost dead; needing a respirator to survive. Dr. Bennett was about to treat him; but decided that - since the man would only live two weeks at most - he would not treat him and unhooked him from the respiator; causing the man to die immediately.
He could have left him on life support and took some time to find any family members he may have so they could make the decisions or at least say goodbye.
he should have seen first in the man had family or friends too make that desion
A homeless man is brought into a hospital and connected to life support. The doctor makes a choice based on personal ethics to disconnect the man from life support; who dies.

He could have let the man stay on the respirator and die in a week or two.  He could have allowed him to stay in the hospital while his potential family could have been located.  He could have brought the subject up to the ethics board at the hospital.

A homeless man whose organs have failed is brought into the emergency room. The doctor makes the decision to let the man die with dignity and shuts off the machine that would keep the man alive for a few more weeks.
He could of asked his family what they wanted to do with the man.
Homeless man enters hospital with injuries that mean he can only live when hooked up to life support. ER doctor feels the man deserves to die with dignity so he unhooks him and the man dies.

A homeless man was dying and a nurse hooked him up to a respirator. The doctor determined that he would only live a few more weeks and never regain consciousness so he unplugged the respirator and let him die.

A very sick unconscious homeless man is brought into an emergency room and hooked up to a respirator. The doctor believing that the man will die regardless decides he wants to give the man some "dignity" by unhooking him from the respirator and allowing hm to die.
He could have tried to contact the homeless man's family. Other homeless people or locals should know his name at least to be able to start tracking his identity.

From a humanitarian perspective; it was probably the right decision to pull the plug. But it's not really his decision to make. The other option would be to leave him hooked up; after which he would shortly die; but all that does is waste hospital resourcs.
He could have let the man continue living until he died naturally in a few days.
The Dr. decided to shut down the respirator.  The man would not live longer than two weeks anyway.
A doctor took a homeless man off of life support so as not to draw out the end of his life.

Passing his photo to homeless services operators in the area to see if anyone knew of any next of kin. 

Give it two weeks and see how he is holding up

it was the best decission he could have made ;it was humane and morally right ..He could have left him hooked up and the cost of it would have been sky high for nothing and noboby would be there to care ;he was going to die anyway ........

A homeless man is brought into a hospital and eventually put on a respirator. It's decided that he most likely will not have much life ahead of him; rather then have him suffer; the doctor pulls the plug on the respirator allowing the man to die with dignty.
He could have left him on the machine and waited to see if by chance anyone who knew him showed up; or he could have asked a supervisor what to do.

A homeless man is brought in and he is hooked up to a breathing machine; without it he will die. The doctor decides to unhook the man so that he can die in dignity since he wouldn't live much longer than a few weeks anyway and will never regain conciousnes.

He was thinking of the growing medical costs to his loved ones if the man spent more time in a hospital with no hope of recovering.  He was also probably thinking about how much this man might hurt other patients who may need the bed.
A unidentified homeless man came into a hospital and was put on life support.  He was going to die in 2 weeks with the life support so the doctor decided to unplug him now.

An unconscious homeless man is rushed into the ER with failing organs. He will die if not put on a respirator; they don't know who he is; and he'll never regain consciousness so the Doctor decides to let him die with dignity.

A homeless man came into an emergency nearly dead and was hooked up to life support.  The doctor's prognosis for the comatose patient was that he would never be able to function again as he had before; and that it would be best if he were taken off life spport to die with dignity.

An unknown homeless man is brought to the ER and hooked up to a breathing machine. Even on the machine the man will only live for a two weeks and will never regain consciousness. The doctor decided the man should have dignity in death and unhooked him fro the machine. The homeless man then dies.
He could have chosen to keep him on life support but that would not have kept him alive indefinitely.
He could have left him hooked to live for a while longer.   Other than that; I'm not sure what he could have done.
Homeless man ends up connected to a life support machine; doctor decides to pull the plug.
A doctor took a homeless man off a respirator.
A man was brought in to the hospital and hooked up to a respirator.  A doctor made the decision to take him off support and let him die.
The doctor believed that the man would die no matter what and deserved to die before suffering any longer.

He could have decided to keep the man on the respirator and devoted the time to keep him alive; even though the expectation was that the man would die within two weeks and never recover. How people respond is never 100%; there may have been a chance the ptient would recover. But he made his best decision within his framework of knowledge.

A homeless man comes into the hospital with his organs shutting down. At the most he could leave for 2 weeks with the help of machines; but the doctor allows the man to die with dignity since he will never regain counsciousness.
A homeless man came to a hospital and there was not much that could be done to extend his life; so the doctor disconnected him from life support
He could have left him connected to the machine and let him live for the few more weeks. He could have also consulted with someone else before making the quick decision.
HE COULD HAVE MADE AN ATTEMPT TO FIND OUT WHO THIS PERSON WAS. HE ALSO COULD HAVE WAITED TO SEE IF HIS CONDITION CHANGED WITHIN A REASONABLE AMOUNT OF TIME.
A homeless man came into the ER unconcious.  His organs were failing and he was hooked up to a respirator of which an ER doctor removed him from to make it so he wouldn't suffer through his death.

An unconscious homeless man is take into an emergency room and is only kept alive thanks to a respirator. The doctor decides that the man will never wake up and disconnects him from the respirator to give him a more dignified death.
Doctor takes pity on dying man. Some might consider this questionable.
A homeless man came in with severe system failiure.  He was hooked up to a respirator but would die in 2 weeks anyway.  Doctor Bennet allowed him to die with dignity.
Homeless man is in ER about to die. Doctor removes respirator to allow for dignified death.
Treat him for a little longer.
Fatally injured homeless man enters ER. Doctor there decides to let him die with dignity.

Dr. Bennett had a homeless patient who was unconscious. With the doctor's help; the patient could have lived for longer but would never have regained consciousness. The doctor decides it is better to let the man die with dignity so he unplugs him from themachines that are keeping him alive.

Dr. Bennet had a homeless man brought in and all his organs were shutting down. He could have let him live for another week or two on automated functions; but he decided to pull the plug on him instead.
A homeless man needs to be connected to a respirator to live. The doctor believes the man should be allowed to pass away and unplugs the respirator.

He could have left him hooked onto the respirator; but then he would have had to divert his attention toward the man just to keep him alive; even though the man would die shorty after. This means the doctor would not be able to focus as much on other patints.
Doctor must decide whether or not to pull the plug on the respirator of a homeless man. He pulls the plug.

The doctor acted impulsively without realizing the gravity of the situation. It's not his right to play God and unhook the machine without consulting anyone else. He should have conferred with colleagues and tried to track down the man's family before takng illegal action like this.

A homeless man came in and was hooked up to a machine so that he could "live" for two more weeks although he wouldn't be conscious. Dr. Bennett decided he should die with dignity and unhooks him from the machine to which he promptly dies.
He could have called the news and had a photograph of the man placed on TV in hopes that someone from his family would recognize him in time for them to say good bye.
A homeless man comes in and is on a respriater to survive. He is not going to last any longer than 2 weeks; so the doctor decided to pull the plug and let the man die with some dignity.
A guy was brought to hospital in critical conditions; and his doctor decided that it would be best for the patient - given his condition - to not continue living.
He could have left the hoeless man attached to the respirator and the man would only live 2 weeks max
He could have kept him hooked up long enough to dig into his identity to possible find a relative that could say their goodbyes as well.

An unknown and unconscious man comes into the ER.  The man will die without the machines; but with the machines will only live a max of two weeks.  The doctor feels the man should be unhooked from the machines; which he does; and the man dies.

I think it was an honorable way for him to die even though he could have kept him alive for a little longer.  Who would have visited him in his last moments and cared about him other than the hospital staff and himself.
He could have kept him connected to the respirator. Meanwhile attempted to find next of kin etc.

A homeless man was brought in to the hospital and could only be supported for 2 weeks on a respirator machine. Since he had no family; the doctor decided to let him have some dignity and die instead of being supported by the respirator.
He could have also just kept him connected to the respirator; but the homeless man would have only lived for another week or two max. I think the doctor made the only rational decision.
Dr. Bennett feels his homeless patients deserves to die with dignity; rather than live for only a week or two longer on a respirator.  He makes the decision to remove him from life support.

A homeless man was in a coma and brought into the emergency room. He is being kept alive with a respirator but wont' live longer than a couple weeks on it. He also does not have a chance of waking up and recovering. The doctor decides to unplug the man an let him die rather than leave him hooked up to the machine. I think that this was wrong. They should have used some time to try and find his family; and if his family couldn't be found; they should have done tests to see if he was an eligible organ donor It just seems like such a waste to me.

A homeless man comes to the ER and needs to be hooked up to a respirator to live; which a nurse does.  The doctor decides to let him die in dignity so he takes him off the respirator; and the man died.

Well; a homeless man came into the hospital and the only way he was being kept alive was by machines. The attending doctor saw this and took pity on the man because the doctor felt that he deserved to pass away with some dignity and the doctor disconnecte the machine and allowed the homeless man to die.
The doctor could have keep the man on the respirators to extend his life in hope a cure would be found to save the man.
Dr. Bennett is an ER physician. An unconscious homeless man was brought in and he had to decide whether he should pull the plug or not. He did.
A doctor realizes that an elderly homeless man has no chance of surviving without a respiratory.  He decides to let him die with dignity; and unhooks him from the respiratory.

The doctor could have run more tests; to see if there was anything they could have done to keep him living. He also could have kept him attached to the machines until they find out who his family is or even who he is; and let their family make that choice He could have attempted surgery or tried antibiotics.
A doctor disconnected a patient from a life machine. The patient; who would have died anyway within 2 weeks; quickly died.
A doctor had to decide whether or not a homeless man should live on life support for two weeks or die the same day; allowing him to die with dignity.
Dr. Bennett is trying to keep the man alive even though he knows he will not live for more than two weeks; so he unplugs all the stuff so he can die with dignity.
His only other real option would have been to treat the man and prolong his life for two weeks. He could perhaps have tried some experimental treatments.

if he was sure he would never regain conscienceness again- then he probably made right decision.  If there was any hope of any kind of recognition then he should do what he could do to keep him alive.  It is very costly to do so; but it is right

A homeless man is taken into the hospital. The man is unconscious and the doctor determines that he will not be able to recover. He will only live for two weeks at the most on life support before dying. So; the doctor wants to let the man die with dignityand unplugs him from life support.
A homeless man came into the hospital hooked up to a respirator. Dr. Bennent knew he would never wake up and would not last longer than two weeks; so he unhooked the respirator and let him die.

A man came into the emergency room. (The man happened to be homeless; which is probably supposed to influence my morality judgement of the doctor's actions.) The man had organ failure and was hooked up to life support. The doctor decided that he shouldn'tdie on life support but rather with dignity; so the doctor disconnected the life support.
A doctor encounters a homeless man in the emergency room who's organs have shut down and he is using a respirator.  He would die without the respirator and only will live for about a week or two.
Maybe he thought that pain is more tougher than living for him; as he will be unable to live or
He could have just left the machine on him ; or maybe ask a doctor for advice.
A man is brought in to a hospital and he will not have any bodily functions ever again. The doctor disconnects him.
He could have kept him on life support for roughly 2 weeks without consciousness until he died.  He could have kept him on life support and see if he survived.
I agree with what he did but I also think they should at least make an effort to see if he has any family first and then pull the plug

A homeless man in brought into an emergency room and Dr. Bennett hooks him up to a respirator which is keeping him alive. He will not be able to live without the respirator and even with it no longer than two weeks so Dr Bennett disconnects him and lets hm die with dignity.
He could have considered leaving him on the machine for a few days so he could try and find an identity and family of the man.

The doctor decided that it wasbest for the man to die with dignity than to live his last days hooked up to a respirator. The doctor decided the fate of this man which is controversial especially for those who believe in miracles.
The doctor basically killed a homeless person who is in coma.
He could have kept the man on the respirator and let him live another 1-2 weeks. He also could have consulted the man's family members instead of making the decision himself.

He could have chosen to keep the man on life support for as long as possible; he could have tried to contact family to see what they wanted; or see if the homeless man (homeless does not mean worthless) had any sort of living will or anything like that.
Dr. Bennett made a decision to disconnect a homeless man from his respirator which quickly killed him.  The homeless man would have only lived for 2 weeks had he stayed connected to the respirator.

He could have left the man hooked to the machine for a few days in order to attempt to find any family members that the man may have. He could have let him die on his own time without intervening. OR he could have kept him on the machine long enough to havest organs for donation.

A homeless man comes into the hospital and is dying; only living because he is hooked up to a respirator. He will die in 2 weeks even hooked up to the machine; so the doctor decides to pull the plug now and let the man die with dignity.

An unconcious homeless man is brought into a hospital. Dr. Bennett notices that he does not have much life left in him; is only surviving because he is attached to a respirator; and will die soon - she decided it would be best to end his suffering and detch him; causing his death.

A homeless man was brought into the emergency room and he was not breathing on his own. After being hooked up to a respirator the doctor decides this man should die with dignity and disconnects the respirator.
A doctor unhooks a terminally ill man homeless man from life support; despite the fact that life support might have extended his life for a week or two.  The man dies.

The doctor has made a life and eath decision for another human being that he does not have the authority to make. It may be the morally superior decision; but it s not his call. Since the man presumedly doesn't have family to make the call; and no medicalrecords to indicate his wishes in such a situation; there isn't really anyone alive who an make that call. In such cases; it makes sense for the medical institutions to preserve life for as long as possible and to save the mercty killings for persons thathave articulated a desire for such an outcome.
The doctor let the homeless man die with dignity

I think he made a good decision. What purpose would it have served to spend all the time and resources to keep him alive when he would never recover; nor regain consciousness. Granted; it would be better if his family could have made that decision; but gien that he was homeless and his family presumably could not be reached; it was a good decision.

He could have kept him on the respirator to ask other opinions or find a hospital that may have a cure; or he could have kept him on the respirator in order to find any relatives or next of kin for the man.
Dr. Bennett gets a homeless man in his Er. He decides to allow him to die; instead of temporarily preserving him on a respirator.

A homeless man who now needs an air machine to breathe will only survive for a few more weeks on it and will never regain consciousness. Because of this; a doctor unplugs the machine and allows the man to die.
As I just said before the survey messed up... The people had different attitudes caused by the catalyst that provoked them.

He could have not disconnected him from the machine and just leave him alone. It's not his right to determine if the person lives or dies. It should be the person itself. If he's unable to decide then it's up to his family. The doctor had aboslutely no riht.
A homeless man has two weeks to live at best.  The doctor thinks he should die with dignity.  He unplugs the respirator and the man dies.
He could have kept the man on the respirator and allowed him to live for 2 weeks.
He could have called local authorities and attemt to find family who would make that decision for him.
He could have kept him alive for a few more weeks; he could have search for close family for the homeless man and let the family decide

I'm not sure if he really made an effort to find out if the man had family somewhere. They could have contacted the police maybe and  used his DNA to identify him and find relatives. I don't think the doctor has the right to decide how the man should die.I understand why he did it; but it was not his choice. It can be argued that this was murder.

An anonymous homeless man is brought into the hospital and placed on a respirator. Since the man will die in a couple of weeks anyway; and has no chance of recovery; Dr. Bennett decides to unhook him so that he can die with dignity.

1) Called another doctor for a second opinion; then proceeded on that basis.

2) Kept the man on the respirator and attempted to find his next of kin before he expired.
He could have let the man linger on the respirator for a week or two before dying anyway.
Kept him on the machine and allowed him to live until he died even on them.
The homeless man could only live if connected to the respirator for only a few weeks.  The doctor decided to disconnect him so he could die with dignity.
The Dr. made a decision to preserve a person's dignity in a hopeless situation.
I agree with his decision; but he probably should have tried to find out his identity first. Then he should have checked to see if he had family so he could see what they might possibly want to do.

A homeless man is admitted to the ER; unconscious and unlikely to recover from his injuries. Dr. Bennett; one of the ER doctors wants him to die with dignity and so unplugs his respirator; allowing the man to die soon after that.
Homeless man comes into hospital. Homeless man is being kept alive by machines. Doctor ends homeless man's life because it is not fulfulling in his eyes.
A homeless man came in and they put him on lilfe support; he was going to die so the doctor let it happen rather then let him suffer

Bennet has two immediate possibilities - to disconnect him or just leave him be.  It is hard to believe that Bennet would refer to the respirator as; "That horrible machine." But if he felt that this case is not worthy of his attention; he can withhold cae. I thought the story implied that the homeless man would need the respirator and some level of care to stay alive for two weeks. Then he doesn't have to make an active decision to disconnect.

Other possibilities seem needlessly complicated (leave himon the respirator; but give him an overdose of morphine; or get Nurse Ratched to care for him).

A severely injured homeless man was brought into the hospital; with no chance of long-term survival. The doctor decided to disconnect the man from live-saving machinery so that the man could die with dignity.
Homeless man is brought to the hospital with no chance of survival.  The doctor thought it was best to let him die with dignity and peace instead of leaving him hooked up to machines.
A doctor mercy killed a homeless man.

It was not fair. The man was unconscious at that point in time and could not discuss this decision with the doctor. The doctor could have waited until either the man awoke; or monitored his condition over a longer period of time before making the decision The doctor could have consulted with colleagues before removing the man from the respirator; in order to be better equipped to make the decision about this man's care (and; ultimately; life).
A homeless man was brought into the hospital and would surely die either now; or in a week or so; so the doctor decided to let him die now.

Dr. Bennet has a homeless guy come in which failing organs and must be connected to a respirator to survive. Dr. Bennet believes the old guy deserves to go with dignity so he disconnects the respirator.
The homeless person was removed from the respiratory because of the doctor's unilateral decision.

The doctor could have consulted other physicians; nurses; or staff. The best thing would have been to consult the legal team at the hospital to make sure what he was about to do was legal. He could have also tried to locate identification.

A doctor is faced with having a patient who is on his deathbed. He can either pull the plug and kill him instantly or he can keep him on the machine; but he'll die within a couple of weeks; so the doctor feels it best to pull the plug to end the suffering
An unconscious homeless man was brought into the hospital. The Dr. on staff didn't want him to live any longer on life support so he unplugged the machine keeping the man alive. The patient died.
He could have kept the homeless man hooked up to the machine till he passed away.
The doctor felt sorry for the homeless guy. So he murdered him.
Homeless man is admitted to hospital; fated to die. Doctor spares him from a miserable; prolonged death and cuts the cord.
Overall I think he made the right choice. Perhaps he could  have waited a day or two for the off chance that some family or something could have been found.
Keep the homeless hooked up to the respirator and try to locate next of kin through DNA.
The story is about a homeless man that arrived to a hospital and is uncouncious. The Dr. say that this man will only for two weeks and then will die; so he was hooked to a breading machine.

The doctor had a choice of keeping the man on a respirator or disconnecting him from the respirator.  The doctor could have keep on the respirator while authorities try to identify the man or his family.  The family could then make the decision to keep th man on the respirator or not.  The doctor should be focus on improve the man's health not making life/death decisions.
He could have found a solution to save his organs within the last two weeks of the patients life.
Morally; I agree with his choice. However; ethically; he denied this patient care without his consent and legally he is liable for that man's death now.

A unconscious homeless man with organ failure is admitted to the ER. The doctor presumes he's dying; and decides to give him "death with dignity" by disconnecting him from a respirator rather than live his last week or 2 in a coma.

The doctor could have chosen to treat the patient and try and help him recover. Although his prognosis was not good it is possible he could have possibly regained consciousness or lived longer than a couple of weeks. He could also have left the homeless mn on a respirator without medical intervention; possibly so that the hospital could try and contact any friends or family of the man and let them decide his fate.
He could have kept him on the respirator.  But as one who would not want to be kept on myself; I think the doctor really wanted to help the man and of course he was saving hospital time and money.
I think that the doctor should not have made that decision and instead; try to find the man's family to determine how they wish to proceed or say their final goodbyes.
A homeless man comes into hospital unconcious and the doctor decides to pull the plug since he is never going to gain conciousness
He could have let the man waste away for two weeks before dying.

DR BENNET IS A EMERGENCY DOCTOR AND IS ON DUTY WHEN THEY BRING IN A HOMLESS MAN IN.HE IS ON A RESPIRATOR AND WILL DIE IN ONE OR TWO WEEKS;BUT DR BENNET PULLS THE PLUG SO THE HOMELESS MAN CAN DIE WITH DIGNITY

Dr. Bennett deals with a terminal homeless patient and decides to let him die. While in many ways this could be the ethically correct thing to do; Dr. Bennet may simply be making the financially prudent decision.
it was a good choice; seeing as it was better to end quickly versus dragging it out for a few weeks for no real reason.
He could have not done it. He could have found the man's family and asked them what they want the doctor to do.
A homeless man is admitted to a hospital.  The doctor realizes that the man will not live long and should die with dignity; so he disconnects the man from the respirator; and the man dies.
I homeless man is taken to the hospital even on life support he will die with e a few weeks. The doctor takes him off life support to allow him to die with dignity
He could have left him alone; and let him die naturally rather than judge for himself what was best for the man.
He could have used him as a donor for a lot of things that weren't going bad he also could have left him plugged in until they found maybe some family of his somewhere and have the make a choice
He could have helped him and let him live for the extra week; you never know what could happen in a weeks time.
He could have left him hooked up to the respirator for a week or two til he died.
He could have harvested his organs for donation. He could have applied medical care to keep him alive.

Dr. Bennet is an ER physician. A homeless man is brought in and all of his internal organs have shut down. Even on a respirator he will still die within two weeks. Dr. Bennet chooses not to use extraordinary measurs to keep him alive.
The doctor decided to take off the machine from the patient; homeless man. The patient will die.
He could have not disconnected the man from the respirator and let him live out his last days. He could have also looked up the man's relatives and asked for their opinion or consent.

A homeless man is admitted to a hospital unconscious and in critical condition. He is stabilized; but only kept alive by a respirator; the attending doctor makes the decision to take him off the respirator and let him die naturally.
He could have let the man live hooked up to machines while in a coma and ultimately dying within 2 weeks. He disconnected the man from the respirator out of mercy.
The doctor pulled the plug on a homeless man that was fated to die.
He could have kept him in the respirator and wasted time and money keeping his body alive.
Attempt to locate the homeless man's family so that they could make the decision on whether or not to disconnect the respirator. Or leave the man hooked up to the respirator until he dies on his own.
A homeless man is in the hospital and a Dr. decides to take him off the machines.
An unknown homeless man came to the ER. His organ systems failed and he was hooked up to a respirator. The Doctor decided he would take him off the respirator.
He could have left him on life support; but he didn't see any reason to since the man would never have woken up. It is possible he could have gotten other opinions from other doctors .

There was a man that had no chance of recovery with his organs shutting down that could have lived via a machine for a couple of weeks but the Dr thought it was better to let him die with dignity so he let nature take it's course.

A homeless man was brought into the hospital in a coma.  He will not wake up and requires life support.  Furthermore; he will not be able to live more than two weeks.  The doctor makes the decision to take hime off life support.
He could have allowed him to live for another two weeks. I would have been pointless because he wasn't going to wake up.

A homeless man is brought into the emergency room in critical condition. He is hooked up to a respirator; but the doctor thinks that the man would be better off dying; so he disconnects the respirator.
A homeless man was brought into the ER. He wasn't going to live more than two weeks; and would rely on a respirator to breathe during that time; so the doctor pulled the plug.
A doctor has compassion for a bady injured man who happens to be homeless. He decides to remove him from life support and the man dies.

Homeless man was brought into the hospital and hooked up to a respirator to save his life. Dr Bennett knows he wouldnt live past 2 weeks with the respirator and thinks he deserves to die with diginity; so he unhooks the man from the machine and the homeles man dies quickly.
An unconscious man came in the emergency room and was clinically dead.  The emergency physician just took off his respiratory machine that keeps him alive and let him die with dignity.

A homeless man was brought in seriously injured.  They didn't know who he was and he was so sick that even with the machine he would only live at most a couple of weeks.  The doctor decided that he didn't think the man should have to live his last two wees suffering and hooked up to a machine to keep him alive.  The doctor decides to unhook the machine; and the man dies.
The doctor could have waited for him to wake up before doing so; or waited to contact his family before disconnecting him.

A homeless man was brought into a hospital and was put on a respirator machine to keep his life going.  He has two weeks to live but the doctor decides to pull the plug so that the homeless man may die with dignity.

The doctor could have simply not done anything but left the man on the respirator. He also could have waited until efforts to locate the man's family have been attempted; so that the decision can be left to his relatives rather than the doctor himself.
He could have left the homeless man on the respirator. The man would have remained a vegetable.
A doctor in an emergency room contemplates whether or not he should let a homeless man die or continue to suffer for another week or two. He decides to turn off his respirator and he dies soon after.
A homeless man is on a respirator and is expected to live for 2 weeks. The doctor doesn't think the man should end his life in such a horrible manner. So the doctor disconnects the machine.
He could've put him on life support; and he would've lived about another week and a half; but would've had no  quality of life; the nurses would've had to do everything for him

I think he made the right decision. His only other option was to prolong a life that was going to end anyhow. I am very much in favor of people being allowed to die with dignity. Also the doctor saved the hospital countless dollars and allowed the respiraor to be used for someone else with a better prognosis.

He is helpless ; homeless and have no identity . Any ways for surely he will die within one or two weaks so the decided to remove the hard machice which makes him truble and the man who got injured died.
A Doctor disconnects an unknown dying unconscious man from a respirator because the doctor thinks he should die with dignity rather than spending weeks hooked up to a machine before dying.
It seemed that the Doctor knew he was going to die any way so why waste the time keeping him alive for an extra week or too. That really was the only other decision die now or die later
He could have left him on the respirator in hopes something could possibly change.

He could have left the man connected to the respirator hoping that there was some unlikely event where the man recovered or left him on the respirator to live out the couple of weeks.  He could have also tried to contact any relatives or people that knew he man if there was any social workers available to do so and let them make the decision.

While what Dr. Bennett did might have been the preferred choice; without knowing the man's wishes or his family's wishes; it can't be known.  Another option would have been to continue keeping the man alive on a respirator until his family could be reache or his identity established.  Absent this information and consent; it might have been more prudent to keep him alive so his family might have been contacted.

The man was being kept alive by unnatural means. Had the respirator not been there; he would have been dead.  He was agreeing with the nurse in that he should die with dignity. He could have kept the man on the respirator and kept him artificially alive.

If the doctor was his heath proxie then he could have used his organs for transplant and kept him alive for those two weeks to find recipients but I do understand why he disconnected him from the respirator.
A doctor needed to be helped and had a respirator hooked up to him
A homeless man was brought in to ER unconscious about to die in two weeks. The doctor thought it would better if he'd die with dignity by disconnecting the respirator.
He could have left it there for the next week.
Homeless man comes in. Is going to die unless he is on a resp system. Doctor thinks the man needs to die with dignity and not be on the system. Doctor pulls plug. Man dies
A homeless man came into the doctors office and he was going to die.  The doctor unhooked the machine that was keeping him alive so that he could die with dignity.
He could have let the man stay hooked up to a respirator; causing the man to live a few more days.
He could leave the man on the respirator. He could try to find the man's family and allow them to make the decision.

The other option would be to keep him on the respirator and possibly search for other procedures in the meantime that would keep him alive. While I don't fully disagree with his disconnecting; I would like to now how long he waited until he did? Like did e just stroll in; shake his head and yank the plug out with gusto?
The Dr decided that there were no live saving measures that would be successful. Based on that knowledge the Dr removed all equipment from the patient.
The obvious one would be to contact the family and find out what they may need. You could also allow the patient to wake and ask him his needs then.
A homeless man comes into the ER and requires machines to live. A doctor disconnects him from the machines and he dies.

i think his decision to remove the man from his respirator was morally wrong; he could have talked to the family of the victim to see what they planned on doing.. for permission to remove him from the respirator. The doctor could have also left him on therespirator and gave him the care he deserved for the remainder of his life
He could have kept him on the respirator
He could have kept him hooked up to the respirator and allowed him to live for a little longer.
A homeless man was brought in and was going to die.  The doctor felt it was more compassionate to let the man die immediately; instead of hooked up to a machine for 2 weeks.
The doctor did not want the homeless man to suffer so he decides not to hook him up to a respirator.
I'm not sure he made the right call.  He may have had family that would have preferred to make that decision themselves.
An emergency room physician removes a patient from a respirator and the patients dies soon afterwards.

A homeless man is brought into an ER and hooked up to machines. The doctor on call discovers that the man will never wake up and will eventually die anyway in a few weeks even being hooked up. Then he decides to let him die with dignity and pulls him fromthe machines.
Dr.Bennett cut off life support for a dying homeless man.

A homeless man was brought into a hospital where he was hooked up to a respirator.  Without the respirator he would die; and with it he would live for a few weeks but remain in a coma like state.  The doctor pulls the plug so the man doesn't have to live n a vegetative state.
I think he shouldn't have done that. I think he should talk to people related to that man or other doctors to see what treatment was available. I don't think he should of done things on his own.
